newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Dec 11.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Dec 11.

text.p: The following stories were reported in Wednesday's edition of The Wall Street Journal:

- Some traders say there is cause to question whether Japanese institutions, which have been big buyers of U.S. Treasury debt securities over the past year and a half, will continue their buying binge.
- Hoechst is expected to announce an offer to buy the 43.3 percent of French pharmaceutical group Roussel-Uclaf that it doesn't already own, in a deal valued at $3.04 billion or more.
- A car maker's group agreed with consumer advocates on a way to test less powerful air bags.
- Ford has run afoul of federal antitrust regulators over its plan to buy Budget Rent A Car.
- Enron said it resumed building its $2.5 billion Dabhol Power Project in India after a 16-month stalemate.
- Cotter's True Value said it would merge with ServiStar in what will create the largest independent chain of hardware dealers in the nation.
- Keyboard makers who haven't put warnings about repetitive stress injuries on their products are the most vulnerable to injury verdicts.
- OSHA is getting ready once again to develop workplace standards to reduce repetitive stress injuries.
- The U.S. current account deficit widened to a record $47.96 billion in the third quarter.
- Regulators are raising concerns about looser terms on syndicated loans, which are made by groups of banks to corporate borrowers.
- Coca-Cola and Cisneros Bottling were fined nearly $2 million by Venezuelan regulators.
- American Express scored a small victory in its battle to market a bankissued charge card in the U.S.
- A growing number of firms are using announcements of purchases by corporate insiders as a means to sing the praises of their stocks.
- The Dow Jones industrials rose, but other indexes fell as investors awaited inflation news.
- Delta Air put its $100 million ad account up for review, potentially ending its 51-year relationship with BBDO.
- Bond prices slipped in quiet trading as investors absorbed a surge of corporate bond issuance while awaiting clearer signs on inflation.
